meanings.definition: To waste (money, time, resources) recklessly or foolishly.
meanings.sent1: She squandered all her savings on unnecessary things.
meanings.sent2: He tends to squander his allowance on toys he doesn't need.
meanings.sent3: Don't squander your time watching mindless TV shows.
meanings.sent4: She squandered her talents by not pursuing her passion for art.
meanings.sent5: It's easy to squander opportunities when you don't plan ahead.

meanings.sent1: The wealthy heiress squandered her inheritance on luxurious vacations.
meanings.sent2: He would often squander his paycheck on expensive dinners and designer clothes.
meanings.sent3: It's hard to resist the temptation to squander money on unnecessary luxuries.
meanings.sent4: She squandered her bonus on a single shopping spree, buying things she didn't need.
meanings.sent5: The company cannot afford to squander its resources on frivolous expenses.

meanings.definition: To fail to take advantage of an opportunity.
meanings.sent1: He would squander every chance to improve his skills by procrastinating.
meanings.sent2: She didn't want to squander the opportunity to travel abroad, so she saved diligently.
meanings.sent3: It would be a shame to squander such a great opportunity for personal growth.
meanings.sent4: Don't squander the chance to learn from your mistakes and grow stronger.
meanings.sent5: They warned him not to squander the opportunity to showcase his talent at the event.
